channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Elmadere Journal: Anger and Grief Simmer in Turkey a Year After Soma Mine Disaster
item.description: Widows of coal miners say they have been left to face the future on their own after an explosion and fire at a mine in Soma killed 301 men in May 2014.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arife Kayrak, 47, lost her husband, Gungor, in the explosion and fire that tore through a coal mine in Soma, Turkey, in May 2014.

item.title: Greece Sends Its Creditors a Proposal Seeking to Break Debt Impasse
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced that his government had sent creditors a final plan to unlock financial aid that the strapped country desperately needs.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Gazans’ Hopes for Rebuilding After War Give Way to Deeper Despair
item.description: Hamas quietly initiated new import fees in an effort to cover the salaries of some 40,000 employees, raising prices in already depressed markets.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunset through a destroyed building on the Gaza shore. Many ruined structures remain from the war with Israel last summer.

item.title: On China’s Yangtze River, a Race Against Time to Find Survivors
item.description: More than 18 hours after the Oriental Star capsized, the vast majority of the 458 people on board were still missing Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A rescue team carried a victim from the Yangtze River in China after a cruise ship capsized in high winds on Tuesday with hundreds on board.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can Kurds Shake Up Turkey's Politics?
item.description: A new party that attracts leftist and Kurdish nationalist voters could spell trouble for Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: U.S. Accuses Syria of Backing Islamic State's Aleppo Advance
item.description: The United States has accused the Syrian military of carrying out air strikes to help Islamic State fighters advance around the northern city of Aleppo, messages posted on the U.S. Embassy Syria official Twitter feed said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Gunmen in Northern Afghanistan Kill 9 Local Aid Workers
item.description: The victims were two drivers, two guards and five staff members of the Czech charity People in Need, the group’s country director said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Push for Colombians to Stop Farming Coca Falls Short
item.description: The effort has gained new urgency since the government’s decision last month to halt an American-backed campaign to kill coca crops with spraying.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Stephen Ferry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anderson Navarro pruning cacao trees on his family farm. Many Colombian farmers have traded in their coca for other crops, growing cacao (for making chocolate), corn and plantains, while also raising cattle for milk and meat.

item.title: Brick by Brick, Nepal Fights to Rebuild
item.description: Following April’s earthquake, young Nepalis organized to bring help and hope where aid groups couldn’t.

item.title: What Silicon Valley Can Learn From Seoul
item.description: South Korean companies are building software for smartphones that’s chaotic, multifunctional and exciting — everything that American apps aren’t.
item.dc:creator: JENNA WORTHAM

item.title: The Agency
item.description: From a nondescript office building in St. Petersburg, Russia, an army of well-paid “trolls” has tried to wreak havoc all around the Internet — and in real-life American communities.
item.dc:creator: ADRIAN CHEN
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: 55 Savushkina Street, last known home of the Internet Research Agency.

item.title: Charles Kennedy, Ex-Leader of Liberal Democrats in Britain, Dies at 55
item.description: The popular leader of the party from 1999 to 2006 opposed the country’s involvement in the Iraq war and resigned after admitting that he had a drinking problem.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Charles Kennedy campaigning in Glasgow in April.

item.title: Hundreds Missing After Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks on Yangtze
item.description: China’s official news agency said the ship sank Monday night in a storm, and as of Tuesday morning, local media reported the rescue of only a small number of people.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: In this image taken from video released by China Central Television, rescuers listened for a response to their tapping on the hull of a capsized ship.

item.title: Bribery Inquiry Drawing Closer to FIFA’s President, Sepp Blatter
item.description: Law enforcement officials said that Jérôme Valcke, FIFA’s secretary general, made a 2008 bank transfer to a soccer official accused of taking a bribe.
item.category: Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF)
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Jérôme Valcke, right, the FIFA secretary general, shook hands with Sepp Blatter at last week's FIFA Congress.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Willy Wo-Lap Lam on ‘Chinese Politics in the Era of Xi Jinping’
item.description: Willy Wo-Lap Lam, a 62-year-old professor at Chinese University of Hong Kong. is the author of five books analyzing China’s top leaders since Zhao Ziyang.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, who has veered away from the “first among equals” approach in favor of the “big boss” model, according to the China scholar Willy Wo-Lap Lam.

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Weather Halts Solar Plane
item.description: A solar-powered plane trying to circle the globe without a drop of fuel made an unscheduled landing late Monday in Japan to wait out bad weather.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: 2 Die of MERS Virus
item.description: The two patients were being treated for respiratory ailments in a hospital last month when they had contact with the nation’s first MERS patient.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: European Leaders Assemble for Urgent Meeting on Greek Crisis
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece is under mounting pressures from many sides, and European leaders hope to help his cash-starved country swiftly meet its financial obligations.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN, NIKI KITSANTONIS and JACK EWING
item.media:description: A Greek newspaper with Prime Minister Alex Tsipras on the cover last week.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Scores Killed as Oil Tanker Crashes Into a Packed Bus Station
item.description: A runaway oil tanker truck exploded in a crowded bus station in Nigeria’s south, setting 12 buses ablaze and killing 69 people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Teachers Union Members Damage Election Offices in Protest
item.description: Members of a radical Mexican teachers union broke into or blockaded electoral offices in Oaxaca State on Monday amid threats to block Sunday’s midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
